TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class MenuItem : ICloneable, System.Web.UI.IStateManager
.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit MenuItem extends System.Object implements class System.ICloneable, class System.Web.UI.IStateManager

Docs.summary: Represents a menu item displayed in the control. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control is made up of a hierarchy of menu items represented by MenuItem objects. Each menu item has a read-only <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Depth%2A> property that specifies the level at which the menu item is displayed in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control. Menu items at the top level (level 0) that do not have a parent menu item are called root menu items. A menu item that has a parent menu item is called a submenu item. All root menu items are stored in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection. Submenu items are stored in a parent menu item's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection. You can access a menu item's parent menu item by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Parent%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collections contain only the menu items for the next level down. To access menu items further down the menu tree, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> property of a subsequent menu item.
To create the menu items for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control, use one of the following methods:
Use declarative syntax to create static menu items.
Use a constructor to dynamically create new instances of the MenuItem class. These MenuItem objects can then be added to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection.
Bind the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control to a data source. When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control is bound to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SiteMapDataSource> control, MenuItem objects are automatically created that correspond to the items in the data source. For other data sources, MenuItem objects are also automatically created that match the hierarchy structure of data source; however, you must also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DataBindings%2A> collection to define the menu item bindings that specify the binding relationship between a menu item and its corresponding data item.
The menu items are displayed in either a static menu or a dynamic menu, depending on its level. The static menu is always displayed in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control. By default, the menu items at the top level (level 0) are displayed in the static menu. You can display additional menu levels (static submenus) within the static menu by setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticDisplayLevels%2A> property. Menu items (if any) with a higher level than the value specified by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticDisplayLevels%2A> property are displayed in a dynamic submenu. A dynamic submenu appears only when the user positions the mouse pointer over the parent menu item that contains a dynamic submenu.
When the user clicks a menu item, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control can either navigate to a linked Web page or simply post back to the server. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.NavigateUrl%2A> property of a menu item is set, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control navigates to the linked page; otherwise, it posts the page back to the server for processing. By default, a linked page is displayed in the same window or frame as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control. To display the linked content in a different window or frame, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Target%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Target%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property affects every menu item in the control. To specify a window or frame for an individual menu item, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Target%2A> property of the MenuItem object directly.
Each menu item has a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> and a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property. The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property is displayed in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control, while the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property is used to store any additional data about the menu item, such as data passed to the postback event associated with the menu item. If you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property, but leave the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property unset, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property is automatically set with the same value as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property. The opposite is also true. If you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property, but not the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property is automatically set with the same value as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > Menu items at the same menu level must each have a unique value for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property; the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control cannot distinguish between different menu items at the same level that have the same value. In this scenario, if the user clicks a menu item that has a duplicate value, the menu item that appears first in the menu is selected.
To display a ToolTip when the user positions the mouse pointer over a menu item, set the item's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ToolTip%2A> property.
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control has several different types of menu items. You can control the style (such as font size and color) for the different menu item types by using the properties in the following table.
|Menu item style property|Description| |------------------------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicHoverStyle%2A>|The style settings for a dynamic menu item when the mouse pointer is positioned over it.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicMenuItemStyle%2A>|The style settings for an individual dynamic menu item.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicMenuStyle%2A>|The style settings for a dynamic menu.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicSelectedStyle%2A>|The style settings for the currently selected dynamic menu item.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticHoverStyle%2A>|The style settings for a static menu item when the mouse pointer is positioned over it.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticMenuItemStyle%2A>|The style settings for an individual static menu item.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticMenuStyle%2A>|The style settings for a static menu.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticSelectedStyle%2A>|The style settings for the currently selected static menu item.|
Instead of setting the individual style properties, you can specify styles that are applied to menu items based on their level by using the style collections shown in the following table.
|Level style collections|Description| |-----------------------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.LevelMenuItemStyles%2A>|A collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItemStyle> objects that control the style of the menu items based on their level.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.LevelSelectedStyles%2A>|A collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItemStyle> objects that control the style of selected menu items based on their level.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.LevelSubMenuStyles%2A>|A collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItemStyle> objects that control the style of the submenu items based on their level.|
The first style in the collection corresponds to the style of the menu items at the first depth level in the menu tree. The second style in the collection corresponds to the style of the menu items at the second depth level in the menu tree, and so on. This is most often used to generate table of contents-style navigation menus where menu items at a certain depth should have the same appearance, regardless of whether they have submenus.
> [!NOTE] > If you use any of the level style collections listed in the previous table to define the style for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control, these style settings override the individual menu item style properties.
In addition to customizing a menu item's style, you can also customize its appearance. You can specify custom images for the different parts for a menu item by setting the properties in the following table.
|Image property|Description| |--------------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ImageUrl%2A>|An optional image displayed next to the text of a menu item.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.PopOutImageUrl%2A>|An optional image displayed in a menu item to indicate that the menu item has a dynamic submenu.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.SeparatorImageUrl%2A>|An optional image displayed at the bottom of a menu item to separate it from other menu items.|
To determine whether a menu item is currently selected in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Selected%2A> property. You can also determine whether a menu item is bound to data by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.DataBound%2A> property. If a menu item is bound to data, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.DataItem%2A> property to access the values of the data item bound to the menu item.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of the MenuItem class, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to populate a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control with static MenuItem objects using declarative syntax.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_177_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_177_1.aspx)]
The following example demonstrates how to bind a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SiteMapDataSource> control. When bound to a data source, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control automatically creates the MenuItem objects. For this example to work correctly, you must copy the sample site map data below to a file named Web.sitemap.
[!code-cs[MenuDataBind#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_177_2.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuDataBind#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_177_2.aspx)]
The following is sample site map data for the previous example.
`<siteMap>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Home.aspx"`
`title="Home"`
`description="Home">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Music.aspx"`
`title="Music"`
`description="Music">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Classical.aspx"`
`title="Classical"`
`description="Classical"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Rock.aspx"`
`title="Rock"`
`description="Rock"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Jazz.aspx"`
`title="Jazz"`
`description="Jazz"/>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Movies.aspx"`
`title="Movies"`
`description="Movies">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Action.aspx"`
`title="Action"`
`description="Action"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Drama.aspx"`
`title="Drama"`
`description="Drama"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Musical.aspx"`
`title="Musical"`
`description="Musical"/>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`</siteMap>`

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class without menu text or a value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class without menu text or a value.
> [!NOTE] > When this constructor is used, all properties in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object are set to their default values. Be sure to set the properties, as necessary, after creating the object.
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItemCtorDefault#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_173_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItemCtorDefault#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_173_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string text) cil managed

Docs.param: The text displayed for a menu item in a control.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified menu text.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class using the menu text specified by the `text` parameter.
The following table shows the initial property value for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A>|The value of the text parameter.|
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-cs[MenuItemCtor1Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_43_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemCtor1Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_43_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string text, string value) cil managed

The supplemental data associated with the menu item, such as data used for handling postback events.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified menu text and value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class using the menu text and value specified by the `text` and `value` parameters, respectively.
The following table shows initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A>|The value of the `text` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A>|The value of the `value` parameter.|
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-cs[MenuItemCtor2Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_156_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemCtor2Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.ui.webcontr_156_1.aspx)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class using the menu text, value, and image URL specified by the `text`, `value`, and `imageUrl` parameters, respectively.
The following table shows initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A>|The value of the `text` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A>|The value of the `value` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ImageUrl%2A>|The value of the `imageUrl` parameter.|
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItemCtor3Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/50183024-d9d9-4104-9a97-_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItemCtor3Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/50183024-d9d9-4104-9a97-_1.aspx)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class using the menu text, value, image URL, and navigation URL specified by the `text`, `value`, `imageUrl`, and `navigateUrl` parameters, respectively.
The following table shows initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A>|The value of the `text` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A>|The value of the `value` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ImageUrl%2A>|The value of the `imageUrl` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.NavigateUrl%2A>|The value of the `navigateUrl` parameter.|
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItemCtor4Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/550462a6-7fba-41a4-a649-_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItemCtor4Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/550462a6-7fba-41a4-a649-_1.aspx)]

.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string text, string value, string imageUrl, string navigateUrl, string target) cil managed

Docs.param: The text displayed for a menu item in a control.
The supplemental data associated with the menu item, such as data used for handling postback events.
The URL to an image displayed next to the text in a menu item.
The URL to link to when the menu item is clicked.
The target window or frame in which to display the Web page content linked to a menu item when the menu item is clicked.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified menu text, value, image URL, navigation URL, and target.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class using the menu text, value, image URL, navigation URL, and target specified by the `text`, `value`, `imageUrl`, `navigateUrl`, and `target` parameters, respectively.
The following table shows initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A>|The value of the `text` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A>|The value of the `value` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ImageUrl%2A>|The value of the `imageUrl` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.NavigateUrl%2A>|The value of the `navigateUrl` parameter.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Target%2A>|The value of the `target` parameter.|
This constructor is commonly used when dynamically populating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Items%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> collection of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use this constructor to create a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is then used to dynamically populate the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-cs[MenuItemCtor5Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/d98f847f-9034-40d5-b483-_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemCtor5Param#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/d98f847f-9034-40d5-b483-_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets a object that contains the submenu items of the current menu item.
Docs.value: A that contains the submenu items of the current menu item. The default is , which indicates that this menu item does not contain any submenu items.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the ChildItems property (collection) to access the submenu items of the current menu item, if any. This collection contains only the menu items at the next level. To access menu items further down the menu tree, use the ChildItems property of a subsequent menu item. If the ChildItems property is `null`, the current menu does not have any submenu items.
The ChildItems property can also be used to programmatically manage the submenu items of the current menu item. You can add, insert, remove, retrieve, and modify <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> objects from the collection. Any updates to the collection will automatically be reflected in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control the next time the page is refreshed.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the ChildItems property to traverse the menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItems#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1311_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItems#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1311_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the menu item was created through data binding.
Docs.value: if the menu item was created through data binding; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The DataBound property is used to programmatically determine whether the menu item was created through data binding.

Docs.summary: Gets the data item that is bound to the menu item.
Docs.value: An <xref:System.Object> that represents the data item that is bound to the menu item. The default value is , which indicates that the menu item is not bound to any data item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control is bound to a data source, such as an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.XmlDataSource> object, this property is set to the data item that is bound to this specific menu item. This property is commonly used to access the value of the data item.
> [!NOTE] > This property is available only after data binding has occurred.

Docs.summary: Gets the path to the data that is bound to the menu item.
Docs.value: The path to the data that is bound to the node. This value comes from the hierarchical data source control to which the control is bound. The default value is an empty string ("").

remarks.format: ## Remarks The DataPath property value is commonly used when calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.IHierarchicalDataSource.GetHierarchicalView%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to provide the path to the data that is bound to the current menu item. This method then returns a <xref:System.Web.UI.HierarchicalDataSourceView?displayProperty=fullName> object that contains the data at the specified path.

Docs.summary: Gets the level at which a menu item is displayed.
Docs.value: The level at which a menu item is displayed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the Depth property to determine the depth of the menu item. The depth indicates the level at which a menu item is displayed and represents the number of levels of hierarchy between the current menu item and the root menu item. For example, a root menu item has a depth of 0. A submenu item of the root menu item has a depth of 1, and so on.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the Depth property to determine the depth of a menu item.
[!code-vb[MenuItemDepth#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_609_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItemDepth#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_609_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the object is enabled, allowing the item to display a pop-out image and any child menu items.
Docs.value: if the menu item is enabled; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When this property is set to `false`, the menu item is disabled and no pop-out image indicating child items is displayed. Setting this property to `false` for a menu item essentially makes the menu item the end of that node, where no further levels are shown off of that node. The default value is `true`.
If you want the menu item to show any child items, but to not be "clickable" itself, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Selectable%2A> property and set it to `false`.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how a menu item with the Enabled property set to `false` appears and functions in a menu.
[!code-cs[MenuSelectableEnabled#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_394_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuSelectableEnabled#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_394_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL to an image that is displayed next to the text in a menu item.
Docs.value: The URL to a custom image that is displayed next to the text of a menu item. The default value is an empty string (""), which indicates that this property is not set.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the ImageUrl property to specify a custom image for the current menu item in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control. This image is displayed next to the menu item text and can be in any file format (.jpg, .gif, .bmp, and so on), as long as the client's browser supports that format.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the ImageUrl property to display a custom image next to the text of a menu item.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_759_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_759_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL to navigate to when the menu item is clicked.
Docs.value: The URL to navigate to when the menu item is clicked. The default value is an empty string (""), which indicates that this property is not set.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A menu item can be in one of two modes: selection mode or navigation mode. By default, a menu item is in selection mode. To put a menu item into navigation mode, set the menu item's NavigateUrl property to a value other than an empty string ("").
When a menu item is in navigation mode, all selection events are disabled for that menu item. Clicking the menu item in navigation mode takes the user to the specified URL. You can optionally set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Target%2A> property to specify the window or frame in which to display the linked content.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the NavigateUrl property to specify the URL to navigate to when the user clicks a menu item.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_431_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_431_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets the parent menu item of the current menu item.
Docs.value: A that represents the parent menu item of the current menu item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the Parent property to determine the parent menu item or to access its properties.
> [!NOTE] > A root menu item does not have a parent menu item.
To access the submenu items of the current menu item, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ChildItems%2A> property.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the Parent property to access the parent menu item of a child menu item.
[!code-vb[MenuItemParent#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_461_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItemParent#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_461_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL to an image that is displayed in a menu item to indicate that the menu item has a dynamic submenu.
Docs.value: The URL to an image that is displayed in a menu item to indicate that the menu item has a dynamic submenu. The default is an empty string (""), which indicates that this property is not set.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuRenderingMode?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `List`, or if <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuRenderingMode?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `Default` and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.PagesSection.ControlRenderingCompatibilityVersion%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `4.0` or later, this property has no effect. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicEnableDefaultPopOutImage%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property or the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticEnableDefaultPopOutImage%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property instead of this property.
If <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuRenderingMode?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `Table`, or if <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuRenderingMode?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `Default` and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.PagesSection.ControlRenderingCompatibilityVersion%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `3.5`, use this property to specify a custom image that is displayed in a menu item to indicate that the menu item has a dynamic submenu. This image can be in any file format (.jpg, .gif, .bmp, and so on), as long as the client's browser supports that format.
> [!NOTE] > Setting this property overrides the image specified by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicPopOutImageUrl%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticPopOutImageUrl%2A?displayProperty=fullName> properties.
You can also disable this image in a static menu by setting this property to an empty string and setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.StaticEnableDefaultPopOutImage%2A> property to `false`. Similarly, you can disable this image in a dynamic menu by setting this property to an empty string and setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.DynamicEnableDefaultPopOutImage%2A> property to `false`.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the PopOutImageUrl property to specify a custom image to display in a menu item when the menu item has a dynamic submenu.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1079_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1079_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the object can be selected, or is "clickable."
Docs.value: if the menu item can be selected; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When this property is set to `false` on a menu item, no action occurs when the menu item is clicked (selected). The pop-out image indicating child menu items for the menu item, if one exists, is still shown and available.
If you do not want any child menu items to appear for a menu item, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Enabled%2A> property to `false`.
Selectable applies only to menu items that can be selected, in the sense that clicking a menu item posts back and sets that item in the selected state. Note that a menu item that cannot be selected is still formatted as a link. This is for accessibility reasons, so that the menu item can cause an action to occur. Also, a menu item, even if it cannot be selected, may have child menu items that can be selected or that need to be displayed.
If you want to prevent a user from clicking a menu item, do one of the following:
- Do not set <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItemBinding.NavigateUrl%2A> and set Selectable to `false`.
- Set the menu item's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Enabled%2A> property to `false`.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how a menu item with the Selectable property set to `false` appears and functions in a menu.
[!code-cs[MenuSelectableEnabled#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_598_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuSelectableEnabled#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_598_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the current menu item is selected in a control.
Docs.value: to indicate that the current menu item is selected in a control; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the Selected property to specify or determine whether the current menu item is selected.
> [!NOTE] > Although the property can be used to determine whether a menu item is selected, it is more common to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.SelectedItem%2A> property.
Only one menu item can be selected at a time in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the Selected property to select a specific menu item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control when the page is first loaded. For this example to work correctly, you must copy the sample site map data below to a file named Web.sitemap.
[!code-cs[MenuItemSelected#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_956_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemSelected#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_956_1.aspx)]
The following is sample site map data for the previous example.
`<siteMap>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Home.aspx"`
`title="Home"`
`description="Home">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Music.aspx"`
`title="Music"`
`description="Music">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Classical.aspx"`
`title="Classical"`
`description="Classical"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Rock.aspx"`
`title="Rock"`
`description="Rock"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Jazz.aspx"`
`title="Jazz"`
`description="Jazz"/>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Movies.aspx"`
`title="Movies"`
`description="Movies">`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Action.aspx"`
`title="Action"`
`description="Action"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Drama.aspx"`
`title="Drama"`
`description="Drama"/>`
`<siteMapNode url="~\Musical.aspx"`
`title="Musical"`
`description="Musical"/>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`</siteMapNode>`
`</siteMap>`

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL to an image displayed at the bottom of a menu item to separate it from other menu items.
Docs.value: The URL to an image used to separate the current menu item from other menu items.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the SeparatorImageUrl property to specify a custom image (usually of a line) that is displayed at the bottom of a menu item to separate it from other menu items. This image can be in any file format (.jpg, .gif, .bmp, and so on), as long as the client's browser supports that format.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the SeparatorImageUrl property to specify a custom image to display at the bottom of a menu item to separate it from other menu items in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1119_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1119_1.aspx)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method hidebysig newslot virtual instance object System.ICloneable.Clone() cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates a copy of the current object.
Docs.returns: An <xref:System.Object> that represents a copy of the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The ICloneable.Clone method is used by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> class to make a copy of itself.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the object is saving changes to its view state.
Docs.value: if the control is marked to save its state; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Typically, you should use the IStateManager.IsTrackingViewState member to determine whether a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> object is tracking view-state changes.
The IStateManager.IsTrackingViewState member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IStateManager> interface.

MemberSignature.Value: .method hidebysig newslot virtual instance void System.Web.UI.IStateManager.LoadViewState(object state) cil managed

Docs.param: An <xref:System.Object> that contains the saved view state values.
Docs.summary: Loads the menu item's previously saved view state.

MemberSignature.Value: .method hidebysig newslot virtual instance object System.Web.UI.IStateManager.SaveViewState() cil managed

Docs.summary: Saves the view-state changes to an <xref:System.Object>.
Docs.returns: The <xref:System.Object?displayProperty=fullName> that contains the view-state changes.

MemberSignature.Value: .method hidebysig newslot virtual instance void System.Web.UI.IStateManager.TrackViewState() cil managed

Docs.summary: Instructs the object to track changes to its view state.

remarks.format: ## Remarks After this method has been called on a server control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.IsTrackingViewState%2A> property returns `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the target window or frame in which to display the Web page content associated with a menu item.
Docs.value: The target window or frame in which to display the linked Web page content. The default value is an empty string (""), which refreshes the window or frame with focus.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the Target property to specify the window or frame in which to display the Web content linked to a menu item when that menu item is clicked. Values must begin with a letter in the range of A through Z (case-insensitive), except for certain special values that begin with an underscore, as shown in the following table. Note that setting this property overrides the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.Target%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control for this menu item.
|Target value|Description| |------------------|-----------------| |`_blank`|Renders the content in a new window without frames.| |`_parent`|Renders the content in the immediate frameset parent.| |`_search`|Renders the content in the search pane.| |`_self`|Renders the content in the frame with focus.| |`_top`|Renders the content in the full window without frames.|
> [!NOTE] > Check your browser documentation to determine if the `_search` value is supported. For example, Microsoft Internet Explorer 5.0 and later support the `_search` target value.
> [!NOTE] > The Target property is rendered as a `target` attribute. The `target` attribute on anchor elements is not allowed in the XHTML 1.1 strict document type definition. Do not set the Target property if the rendered output for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.HyperLink> must be XHTML 1.1-compliant. For more information, see [XHTML Standards in Visual Studio and ASP.NET](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). > > When creating accessible Web pages, it is strongly recommended you avoid using the Target property to target another window. For more information, see [Accessibility in Visual Studio and ASP.NET](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the Target property to specify a window or frame in which to display the Web content linked to a menu item when that menu item is clicked.
[!code-cs[MenuItemTarget#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_39_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemTarget#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_39_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text displayed for the menu item in a control.
Docs.value: The text displayed for the menu item in the control. The default is an empty string ("").

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the Text property to specify or determine the text that is displayed for the menu item in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
> [!NOTE] > If the Text property contains `null`, the `get` accessor returns the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property, in turn, contains `null`, <xref:System.String.Empty> is returned.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the Text property to specify the text to display in each menu item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_246_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_246_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the ToolTip text for the menu item.
Docs.value: The ToolTip text for the menu item. The default is an empty string ("").

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the ToolTip property to specify the ToolTip text for the menu item. The ToolTip text is displayed when the mouse pointer is positioned over the menu item.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the ToolTip property to specify a ToolTip for each menu item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
[!code-vb[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_509_1.aspx)] [!code-cs[MenuItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_509_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a non-displayed value used to store any additional data about the menu item, such as data used for handling postback events.
Docs.value: Supplemental data about the menu item that is not displayed. The default value is an empty string ("").

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Value property is used to supplement the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property by storing any additional data associated with the menu item. This value is not displayed in the control and is commonly used to store data for handling postback events.
> [!NOTE] > If the Value property contains `null`, the `get` accessor returns the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Text%2A> property, in turn, contains `null`, <xref:System.String.Empty> is returned.
The value of the Value property is also used when the value path specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.ValuePath%2A> property is generated. A value path is a delimiter-separated list of menu item values that forms a path from the root menu item to the current menu item. The value path is used to indicate the position of a menu item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control.
> [!NOTE] > Menu items at the same menu level must each have a unique value for the Value property; the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control cannot distinguish between different menu items at the same level that have the same value.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to display the Value for a menu item and its parent when the user selects a menu item.
[!code-cs[MenuItemValue#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_424_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemValue#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_424_1.aspx)]

Docs.summary: Gets the path from the root menu item to the current menu item.
Docs.value: A delimiter-separated list of menu item values that form a path from the root menu item to the current menu item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The ValuePath property contains a delimiter-separated list of menu item values that form a path from the root menu item to the current menu item. The value path is used to indicate the position of a menu item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control. You can specify the delimiter character used to separate the menu item values by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.PathSeparator%2A> property. This value is commonly used when parsing the list for the individual values, or to pass as an argument to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu.FindItem%2A> method of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TreeView> class. Depending on the value displayed in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control, the delimiter character might need to be changed to prevent any conflicts. For example, if you set the delimiter character to a comma, the displayed value should not contain any commas; otherwise, you cannot accurately parse the ValuePath property.
> [!NOTE] > The values of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property of each menu item from the root menu item to the current menu item are used to generate the value path. Menu items at the same menu level must each have a unique value for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MenuItem.Value%2A> property; the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Menu> control cannot distinguish between different menu items at the same level that have the same value.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to parse the value to the ValuePath property for the individual menu item values.
[!code-cs[MenuItemValuePath#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1342_1.aspx)] [!code-vb[MenuItemValuePath#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_1342_1.aspx)]
